Currently our older youth are awash in a culture that promotes evil, occultism, lust and power for its own sake. The magick world-view is all around them. It is promoted in Television, movies and music and increasingly on the internet. Witchcraft on the internet is often coupled with pornography. Ask any teenager to open the latest anime’ site such as the Japanese version of Dragon Ball Z and one can find EVERY kind of pornographic material. Teens are readily playing the older game of Dungeons and Dragons and Magic the Gathering. Think about it. We now have several major TV shows where the heroes are witches, vampires, and movies where the good guys do supernatural feats. In our insecure family structure of today, much trauma has been handed to our children. Witchcraft and practices of the occult promise them the ability to control their lives, when their lives are spinning out of control. People always seek to ease the trauma they are in, and fairy godmothers are not at all what they seem to be!

There's no question over whether an asteroid hit. The roughly 6-mile-wide (10-kilometer) space rock carved out the Chicxulub crater off Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. Previous work uncovered a global layer of material that had melted and then hardened when the impact vaporized terrestrial rock. Robertson and his colleagues argue that superheated stuff was blasted from the crater into a suborbital path around Earth, generating a "heat pulse" upon re-entry. "The kinetic energy of the ejected matter would have dissipated as heat in the upper atmosphere during re-entry, enough heat to make the normally blue sky turn red-hot for hours," Robertson said. All unprotected creatures were "baked by the equivalent of a global oven set on broil."

" next friday: The Dark Side of Harry Potter Written by: Natalia Olenicoff The Prisoner of Azkaban reveals darker troubles for Potter The latest Harry Potter film, set to hit the big screen on June 4th, is said to have a refreshingly different feel to it than the first two films. Critics have commended the new film for delving into the darker side of the young wizard’s story. Unlike the first two films, which entertained the audience with fantastical Disney-looking sets and characters, The Prisoner of Azkaban is set predominantly in a dark, rainy world, where Potter seeks out his parents’ alleged murderer who has escaped from the prison. In this film, Potter’s character exhibits more of his inner turmoil over his parents’ death and his predestined role in wizardry. Fans of the first two films should not be disappointed by the series’ darker third installment, though. Director Alfonso Cuaron whipped up another extraordinary adventure film with enough magic to make even the most committed realist wish for a magic wand.

an urlLink interview with billy corgan on the state of rock today. Is it impossible for a great icon to come along again? What we’re going to see now is a different archetype rise up. It’s not going to be the Elvis archetype; it’s going to be something we can’t even imagine. It’s going to be someone, maybe, who’s more spiritual, somebody who doesn’t want anything to do with corporate industry. Somebody who’s an Internet star. Some kid who makes tapes in his bedroom and says, "F---the world. This is my version of it." And then people will latch on. All the music factories in the world can’t manufacture that kid. To me, Elvis was the innovator. We’ve basically just been watering down Elvis. We’ve lost the desire to support individuals. In the early ’90s, you had six or seven top people—Courtney [Love], Trent Reznor, Soundgarden, Alice in Chains. We all got assassinated because we didn’t live up to some sort of idealism that never existed: a perfectionism of rock and roll attitude mixed with drug addiction. So what replaced us? Kids who looked the part, acted the part, but they weren’t saying the same things. They’ve been successful, so why would the next generation go back to what we used to do?

from urlLink news of the weird : Although 50 countries (including Japan) have now banned American beef because of inadequate mad-cow controls, the U.S. Department of Agriculture not only has declined to order widespread testing but has even prohibited one farm, Creekstone (Campbellsburg, Ky.), from voluntarily testing. USDA said such conscientious testing would imply that America's entire 35 million yearly slaughters should be tested (which the industry says is too expensive, even though Japan requires universal testing for its beef). USDA said it aims to test only 40,000 cows, up from 20,000 for the last two years (although it has been unable for nine months now to document those tests in response to a Freedom of Information Act request by United Press International). i managed to get a good 9 hours last night! and i had a wacky dream. first, i had a houseguest coming to stay with me who was really really finicky. like, the A/C (which i don't have) had to be off, every window in the apartment had to be closed, and anything that made noise in the night (eg, the refrigerator) had to be unplugged, 'cause he was so picky about sleep. then, there was a part where i was walking down the street with my parents, but i've forgotten what happened there. then i was at a fancy restaurant. and then i was at a mexican grocery store, and i could speak spanish, and the girl at the door let me have a free container of godzilla themed chorizo. and then i woke up. the advanced celebrity skinniness research institute has found a new technique for making the olsen twins look even skinnier ! stand 'em next to jack osbourne! note the protruding shoulder blade of the twin on the left: here's an entertaining excerpt from the urlLink toothpaste for dinner guy's latest mass mailing: it is friday and that means that, at nine o'clock in the morning, most of you are already at work slacking off. it's okay. one of my favorite things to do used to be to make sculptures out of liquid paper by painting over a bump over and over until it built into a statue an inch high or so. but i quit when too many statues got inadvertently lost or broken, shuffled under some papers or knocked over by a coffee mug. too many broken dreams, too many smashed-up fantasies to keep going! before i started to conserve my "free time at work" for answering emails and drawing pictures, i used to produce great anthropomorphic animal charts for any assignment for which i was required to make a chart. the weirdest part about work was that nobody ever said anything about it. here i was, drawing faces and legs on pie charts, and i guess people thought i was just some kind of misguided clip-art user and they felt kind of embarrassed. NOBODY EVER SAID ANYTHING ABOUT IT. that is kind of oppressive, i think it is why i stopped doing it. you would think that reasonable adults would see some data surrounded by illustrations which clearly reference the tone and manner of childrens' books, and see that my powerpoint illustration was not only absurd but a little bit insulting to everyone who read it.

urlLink Relatives of troubled pop beauty Britney Spears are seriously worried about her mental health - after she rushed off stage in Berlin, Germany in tears. The Toxic superstar, 22, has been struggling to cope with her huge workload as she continues her Onyx Hotel tour in Europe, and sources close to Britney fear the situation is only going to get worse. Britney is reportedly desperate to return home to her mother Lynne after suffering the worst reviews of her career for the raunchy stage show. But with contractual obligations preventing her from ditching the tour, miserable Britney is getting more and more depressed. And the depth of her anguish was clearly demonstrated when she ran off the stage in the German capital and fled to a waiting car, before ignoring fans as she ran into her hotel. A source tells British newspaper the Sun, "Dozens of fans were waiting for her outside the hotel. She rushed straight past them with her baseball cap pulled right down over her eyes. But everyone could see she had been crying her eyes out on the limo journey. Her mascara was streaming down her face." Maybe she's upset about this: Antonio Banderas was so moved while watching his eagerly-anticipated new movie Shrek 2 with Justin Timberlake, he ended up sobbing and holding hands with the pop hunk... Banderas says, "I was kind of crying at the end of the thing. It was kinda funny because there's is a very romantic moment at the end of the movie. My character says, 'I wanna cry,' and I was crying. Cameron Diaz was (to the left) and Justin Timberlake was (to the right), and he said to me, 'I'm crying too!' urlLink So we held hands for a while . urlLink http://quebolu.galeon.com/imagenes/britney.jpg Wait, there's more! urlLink Britney Spears says she doesn't think she's remotely sexy. She says that while people may think she has a glamorous life, she's often really just trying to survive. "I don't consider myself sexy at all," the 22-year-old pop star told German FHM magazine, claiming she couldn't understand why she had become the subject of so many men's fantasies. However, she said she does think women who are confident about their sexuality are sexy, and that she has secretly been just as sexually active as Janet Jackson. "I may not brag about it as much," said Spears. "But as far as sex goes, I've done similar things to what Janet Jackson has done."

Pope John Paul II was born "Karol Josef Wojtyla" on May 18, 1920 in Wadowice, Poland. He was the second son of a retired army lieutenant named Karol Wojtyla and a schoolteacher named Emilia Kaczorowska Wojtyla. He had one elder brother named Edmund (a physician) who died from scarlet fever at age 26. He also had an elder sister named Olga who died in infancy. His mother died from kidney disease and heart failure in 1929. In high school, the future pope became interested in literature and especially acting. He acted in several local plays before enrolling in Krakow's Jagiellonian University. While at Jagiellonian, he studied Polish literature and was a member of the Krakow Theatre Brotherhood. In 1942, he began studying in secret for a life in the priesthood. In 1944, members of Krakow's "underground seminary" were captured and executed by the Nazis. The Pope himself narrowly escaped death (as soldiers failed to notice him hiding behind a door). He was ordained a priest in 1946 and in 1978 became the first non-Italian pope in 455 years. At age 58, he was also the youngest pope in more than a century. Read the details of his ordination in the October 16 "Deming Headlight".

The I Know What You Did Last Summer beauty met with an actor posing as a casting director, who excited her with the prospect of starring in a false World War II epic called Wages Of War as Pitt's sister. But her smiles were soon wiped away when the 'agent' revealed he'd lost a ton of money on a bad Super Bowl bet and his life was at risk unless he paid up immediately. When the two 'debt collectors' charged into the office, a visibly shaken Love Hewitt attempted to exit the office, moments before learning it was all just a prank. And while she was relieved to be safe, the lost opportunity to work with Pitt was clearly disappointing. While recovering from her trauma, she asked Kutcher, "I'm not really gonna get to be in a cool movie, am I? Darn it!" The episode aired in America on Sunday night.

urlLink article But in recent years, many election officials have been building a variety of hurdles to make it more difficult for students to register and vote. In May 2002, the city council in Saratoga Springs, New York, shut down a polling place at Skidmore College, forcing students to travel off-campus to vote. That same year, a judge in Arkansas tried to block 1,000 students at Ouachita Baptist University and Henderson State University from casting ballots, ruling that they must vote in their hometowns -- even though the deadline for absentee ballots had already passed. And when students from the University of New Hampshire showed up at the polls on Election Day that year, poll workers handed them a pamphlet warning them that voting locally could affect their financial aid and taxes. The scare tactic worked: Many students left without voting.

DEAR ABBY: I recently became engaged to a man I thought was the salt of the earth. Then I moved in with him. Well, he's not the man I thought he was. I now know that almost everything he has told me is a lie. He's 12 years older than he said. He never went to college like he claimed. He told me he was sterile, but I discovered he has four children. He pays child support for two of them who are very young, so he'll be obligated for a long time. His parents are both living -- not dead like he told me -- and he's not an only child; he has two brothers who live across the country. My mind is spinning. We're supposed to be married in three months. I'm seriously thinking about breaking the engagement and moving out, but I still love him. Should I stick it out and hope for the best, or listen to my gut? --SECOND THOUGHTS IN INDIANA

Lansbury Slams Decision To Remake 'Manchurian Candidate' Angela Lansbury has registered her strong displeasure at the decision to remake the classic 1962 film The Manchurian Candidate, in which she starred with Frank Sinatra. In an interview with syndicated columnist Liz Smith, Lansbury, best known in recent years for her starring role on the TV series Murder, She Wrote, remarked: "I'm so unhappy. I'm so sorry they had to mess with something that was so perfect." In the new film, set for release on July 30, her role is played by Meryl Streep. "I have great admiration for Meryl Streep," Lansbury told Smith. "She'll probably be very interesting. I just wish she hadn't chosen to do it."

But even though I rarely indulge it, I'll admit to having an airport fetish. Back when I was a young aesthete, besotted with all that was tacky, the kitsch I loved most was a category I dubbed "the Superbland." The Superbland was anything that was so lacking in character (innate or borrowed) that it screamed with existential nothingness. Office cubicles were Superbland. Modest, non-brand-name khaki pants with pleats in the front were Superbland, especially if paired with muted-color cotton/poly blend plaid shirts (the plaids had to be small). And airports were the mother of all Superblandness, providing a frisson (albeit an ironic one) of excitement.

Recall in our hero's last post that he found a new series called Comic Party . Recall further that Comic Party was about doujinshi (fan made comics). So, imagine our hero's delight when he finds Comic Party doujinshi! That's right: fan comics about a series about fancomics. What's funnier? It's professionally produced by CPM. I just coundn't resist that through the looking glass shit so I picked up a copy. The girl behind the counter grinned. She knew what I was in for. A bit more background: Comics Party has about 8 characters. One main guy, his crazy friend, and several women between the ages of 18 and 25. Total people? ~8. Total penises? 2. Everyone got that little fact in mind? Within the first 5 pages there's allusions to some non-consentual sex. BETWEEN THE TWO GUYS. Oh, one of the girls wants "models" for her yaoi doujinshi (fan-made Gundam Wing comics. Okay, not always GW, but whereever there are two Japanese men being drawn having sex the spirit of Duo is not far away) and one of the guys was perfectly willing! The other guy's opinion didn't really matter.... *shudder*. The third story featured pictures of "Crazy Friend" offering his almost nude body to the main character. Then two stories later the main guy has to draw himself and his partner (no, not the female partner!) getting freak nasty for a fan. All in all, about 1/3 to 1/2 of the stories feature the only two Y chromosome possesing characters in various compromising positions. "But," you say, "that's okay, right? I mean, the other stories have to be about what happens when all the female characters go over to each other's houses after a long day's work and relax with two or more glasses of wine and some soft music and low lights and maybe a jello pit and some pillows and babydoll tees, right? There should be equal time, right?" Wrong. WRONG. Not even the angry girl with short hair tried to get some lesbian action, and if there's anything that I've learned from my 24 years on this earth it's that cute evil girls with short hair are ALWAYS 2 drinks away* from a girl-on-girl adventure. The authors weren't having any of that shit. I flipped over to the table of contents to see who wrote each story and sure enough: all of the authors were women. No wonder the clerk at Waldenbooks grinned like that. I give it 3 stars. *or "me asking them out".

so, i was rudely awakened by the downstairs neighbors this wknd. i think the woman was talking loudly on the phone (either that or she was talking to herself or watching tv). eventually, i gave up hope that she'd stop on her own, so i broke out the international signal of apartment noise-related fury and stomped on the floor a couple of times until she caught on. after that, i had a weird dream. rui and i had decided that instead of me flying to tucson or her flying to seattle, we should *both* fly to london for the wknd. it was 10:20 at night the day before my flight and i was in a panic trying to find an open bookstore b/c i didn't have any kind of guidebook to london. i was freakin' out! i think i was stressing about flying home this wknd. i have to use alaska again (gray! tell your dad to tell SWA that i need later friday-night flights to sacramento from sea-tac, ok?). and the early times at which the bookstores close around here. john kerry has raked in urlLink $100million in three months . many people are advising john kerry to just urlLink stay back and be invisible , letting the bush campaign self-destruct. also, it's urlLink harder to reach voters nowadays . there's more tv channels, we get so many political mailings that they all go straight into the trash, and increasing numbers of people refuse to participate in telephone polls. on the other hand, it makes it easier to send targeted messages. like, if i wanted to reach the "rui" target demographic, i could broadcast my pro-ham ads on the ham channel, whereas i would reach the "gray" target demographic by showing pro-cake ads on the cake channel. speaking of political mailings, never ever donate money to anyone. i decided to participate in the giving campaign at work last year, and ever since, i have been *bombarded* with political mailings from anyone who thinks i might possibly be interested in giving them money. and they're very creative at making the mail look actually important so you don't throw it out instantly; your first thought is "crap, is this jury duty? or did i forget to pay my bills for six months? is there a warrant out for my arrest?" when really it's just the american ham foundation trying to solicit donations to buy sandwiches from the olsen twins. Additionally, i get bombarded with mail from companies who took my address from our domain name registration and think i'm a corporation. i get tons of corporate credit card offers, cell phone package deals for 50+ users, big office supplies catalogs... i'm tempted to start stamping "deceased" on them and sending them back, but i've heard horror stories where they report to everyone that you're deceased and pretty soon the coroner shows up and tries to drag you to the morgue. well, not actually the coroner thing, but i've read articles where the "deceased" message gets to the wrong people and your insurance gets canceled or something. 9/11 was originally to involve urlLink ten airplanes instead of just four , and they wanted to hit targets on both the east and west coasts (including the tallest buildings in CA and WA). urlLink pearl jam's gone acoustic ! j.ro suggested adding a link to the kim jong il blog, but it hasn't been updated in six months.. it's funny as hell though. i'm trying to remember to add the comic he suggested too. the rest of you should suggest sidebar links (comics, blogs, random stuff) too. or anything to put on the sidebar. there's lots of space! and gray is evil. yesterday i tried to IM him and he was all "i'm leaving, ham!" and then today he managed to sign off in the second btwn when i opened a window to type a message and when i hit "enter" to send it. EEEE!!!! i just got an awesome email! i have to go do the i-get-a-huge-new-flatpanel-monitor dance! man, now my normal-sized monitor at home is going to feel even more cramped. i'm far too cheap to buy a LCD monitor for myself. i've been thinking about trying to clear space on my desk. for instance, i never use the printer. i've actually been toying with the idea of completely rearranging my apartment. like, i could put my bed in the dining area and have what's now my bedroom be the computer and guitar area. it might help the yapping/snoring neighbor problem. i'd probably just find out that the other neighbors are noisy 5AM breakfast-eaters or something. i think the people next door think i'm weird and creepy. i was looking at a strange object on the fire extinguisher box (it turned out to be a broken bicycle reflector) just as the neighbors opened their door, and i think they thought i was standing right outside their apartment staring at their door. sigh. here's my apartment in ASCII (for no good reason): +------+------------------+ | Clo- CDs | | set Bed | +------+ | | | D | | Bath | e | | room | s | | | k | | +- +---+- -+ | Clo| Closet | | set| | +------+ +---+--------+ | | | Gui- Kitchen | | tars | | | | ----------+ +------+ TV | | | | | Coat | | Clo- Gui- | | set | tars | +------- E | R/ | Futon I/| +-DOOR-----------------F/-+

-Ive found a new manga series that I really like! Comic Party is a quirky little series about the world of Japanese doujinshi (fan comics) authors. The characters are really cute: theres the boy who wants to dominate the worlds culture through doujinshi, the main characters girlfriend who carries a NAIL BAT (FFVII style), and Chisa, the cute crazy girl. When a heavy cart shes pushing goes out of control and is sort of dragging her behind, she doesnt just say Oh shit! or Get out of the way!. No, its I cant stop this thing! Or global warming! Or the recession! Chisa falls powerless before the merciless law of inertia! all said while said cart rolls uncontrollably. The little shout outs to the fandom are cute too: from the fact that the doujinshi they make in the comic actually ARE based on real anime/manga/game series like To Heart and Parappa the Rappa to the inclusion of anime fan stereotypes like Fat Sweaty Bastard Who Doesnt Shower During the Entire Goddamn Convention and Has Never Heard of Deodorant and is a Complete Dick. Seriously, he gets around to every fucking con. The animated series, of course, is completely devoid of all of the humor and insanity of the comic. Its looking like Love Hina started a trend. Also, both comics need more titties. -I wanted to tell Clara about urlLink Boku no Futatsu Tsubasa , but I didnt think that she wanted to hear about a comedy manga that starts with incest and then gets weirder while she was work. The English scan-lation can be found at http://www.adtrw.org/tsubasa.php. Oh, and the slang for she had sex with another girl seems to be she pushed her down. Clara, stay the hell out of Japan. -If you like Dragon Ball Z, youll like urlLink ButtLord GT . If you hate Dragon Ball Z but were forced to learn something about it, youll probably be highly amused by urlLink ButtLord GT . http://www.atomictoy.org/comics/buttlordgt/buttlordgt.html">ButtLord GT -AD Vision, Gainax, and WETA (the guys behind the special effects for Lord of the Rings) are coming together to urlLink completely fuck up one of my favorite series, Neon Genesis Evangelion . Yes, the original Evangelion has its share of problems, but its fun as all hell to watch and did break the giant robot saves mankind genre wide open during the mid 90s. Having them cut it down to less than three hours and then change the cast/story to allow more white people in it (Asuka was hafu, all the other main characters were full Japanese) is like hearing theyre going to redo I'm Gonna Get You Sucka for a 30 minute TV episode and cast Jen and Ben in the lead roles. Urg.

"mr ed"... hey, here's a question for you all. i've always enjoyed the previews when i go to a movie, but some people seem to hate them with a passion. my feeling is that i like to know what's coming soon (either to see it or to avoid it...), plus they're entertaining, plus it means the movie is about to start and you don't have to sit through the stupid advertising slideshow anymore (does anyone actually pick a realtor because of an out-of-focus slide they saw before bubble boy started?). i mean, i hate it when they run video ads for products before a movie, but it seems entirely appropriate to show movie previews. do any of you have strong feelings against movie previews? i had a weird dream last night. i don't remember most of it anymore, but i do remember that when i looked in a mirror, my nose was enormous. i mean, not just a big nose: it was like the sort of crazy nose you'd find in a picasso painting. it was a relief to check it in the mirror this morning and find it nose-sized. speaking of noses, you should head over to urlLink awfulplasticsurgery.com and take a gander at the picture of lance bass's new nose. it looks awful. i mean, before he was kind of goofy-looking but his features went together ok. the new nose just looks alarmingly weird with the rest of his face, and it draws attention to the fact that he has kind of strange eyes. oh, and if you look at your profile on urlLink blogger.com (you may have to create one first!), it'll tell you how many times you've posted, how often you post, how many external links you've posted, how many words you've written, etc. etc. kind of interesting.

i found the perfect place to live while rui and i were in LA. they built new apartments on urlLink sunset & vine across the street from amoeba music and the cinerama. on the ground floor, there's a border's books and a baja fresh ! sadly, the website won't tell me how egregious the rents are, so i'm going to have to email them. i bet it's insane. i don't really care, except that everyone keeps saying that they don't think the rents are as insane as i think they are, and i want to prove them wrong wrong wrong. ah. urlLink someone's blog says 1br's start at over $1550/mo. which is not nearly as ridiculous as i thought it might be. unfortunately, i already submitted the "send me more info" form, so now i'm going to be spammed with info i don't care about. dammit. i have an appointment with the throatdoctor tomorrow -- my throatglands have been sore ever since the last time i had a throatdisease, so the doctor thought i should go see someone who knows about throats. i'm guessing it's allergies or stress or something, but the doctor said she didn't think it sounded like allergies or stress. but then, she's not a throatdoctor, so what the hell does she know? the whole LA trip felt very surreal to me. i think it was because my sleep schedule was off (i woke up at 3:30AM to fly to burbank on thursday) and i spent four days gallivanting all over town. there were points where we were driving and i kept thinking i was in seattle and then i had to remind myself that we weren't and my brain was just utterly confused. i mean, in four days, i went to: burbank airport (2x), LAX (2x), santa monica (2x), venice beach / muscle beach (2x), shopping on melrose, amoeba (went in 2x, no parking 2x), hollywood & highland mall, colorado blvd (2x), warszawa, nova express (got coffee once, no parking once), el portal, equator (café in pasadena), beverly hills, west hollywood, drove along the PCH past malibu (2x), random drive east of arcadia, little tokyo (i got 2kg of those rice-brick things!), and probably more that i've forgotten. the hotel was in arcadia, which was not exactly central to the gallivanting. it was, however, nonmurderghettoey. dodge stratuses (strati?) guzzle gasoline like crazy. oh, and i drove past the old tenement at 210 south catalina; i was surprised to find it still standing. i read rolling stone on the flight to LA. they had an interesting article on how the dean campaign imploded (at least i think it was in rolling stone -- i read a bunch of magazines). it was really interesting. apparently dean and trippi (his campaign manager) hardly talked to one another and trippi was paranoid about losing control, so he wanted to be included in every meeting that anyone had about anything, and he refused to go to iowa even though he's supposed to be an iowa caucus strategymaster. and everyone who worked for the campaign was scairt of trippi, so when he did something stupid, they were afraid to suggest that maybe it wasn't the best course of action. oh, and al gore seems to be fat again: maybe it's just a bad photo?

i'm back. i had a lovely four days in socal. i flew in thursday morning and wandered around for a day and a half until rui flew in friday evening. it was very warm and sunny. i got a sunburn! i should take a picture of my watch tan so you'll all believe me. :) after i flew in on thursday, i went to pasadena to get a goldstein's bagel for breakfast. i was wandering around eating my bagel when this girl stopped me and asked, "excuse me, do you live around here?" and i replied that i used to but that i no longer did. she asked where i lived now, and i said seattle. then she said something like, "ah, ok, that explains it." and the conversation was clearly over. does anyone have any idea what the hell this was about? I was mistaken for an amoeba records employee at the store, and once at the airport on the way back (i was wearing an amoeba shirt). i was also mistaken for an employee in a vintage t-shirt shop on melrose. and an italian guy gave me his phone number on the beach. i gave the number to rui when she showed up, but she didn't seem to want another boyfriend. i spent several hours at the beach in santa monica on friday (where i got sunburned) and several more on saturday (where i got a sunburn on top of my sunburn). the ocean rocks. food i ate: - el pollo loco - goldstein's bagel - warszawa - el portal - gelato - a sandwich from this awesome shop in beverly hills - ice cream at venice beach - roscoe's fried chicken

urlLink link Researchers gave 322 patients underarm injections of either Botox or salt water. They received 12 to 14 injections per armpit. Although injection site pain was the main side effect, lead investigator Dr. Dee Anna Glaser of St. Louis University School of Medicine said the needles are so tiny that most patients weren't bothered. A month later, 75 percent of the Botox users reported a significant decrease in sweating, compared with a quarter of the placebo patients, said Glaser, who is to present the study at this weekend's American Academy of Dermatology meeting. Patients could get additional rounds of injections every few months, but 43 percent got relief for a year from the first treatment, Glaser said. The median duration of response was about six months.

P-chan: Oh, one of the comics I'm reading. GANTZ. It makes no sense. All is has is violence and naked women. I have no idea why I'm reading it. P-chan: It's up to chapter 121. Gray: I'm trying to imagine the writer... Maybe he saw this one episode of 'Jackson' where Jackson picked up a car or something. Gray: "All is has is violence and naked women. I have no idea why I'm reading it." Oh, I think you do. I think you do. GANTZ really is crap. I mean really really crappy. I get the feeling that this is going to be the new Ninja Scroll or DBZ : the series that, when I say that I like anime, people say "Oh yeah? Have you seen ______? It's so awesome!" and I cringe. Before you ask, NO, I have not seen Ninja Scroll nor do I have any real interest in seeing it. GANTZ though... it's terrible... but you just can't look away. Let me introduce you to the main characters: This is our hero, Kei. When we first meet him he's all excited because a homeless man is going to be run over by a JR light rail train. And I don't mean "distressed", I mean "Shit, gimmie some popcorn! This is gonna be awesome." He's a real rolemodel This is our hero's friend, Masaru. He's the goodie goodie. He wants to save crazy homeless guy and manages to get Kei to help. Oh, how noble. Guess what, bitch? The joke's on you: once you help crazy homeless guy off the track, no one is there to assist you and Kei! KERUNCH. Kei and Masaru wake up to find their heads attached to their bodies and said bodies not under the wheels of a train. They're in a small room with some other confused people who remember dying and... a black ball. This is not ordinary black ball, this is GANTZ. GANTZ commands them to kill aliens for points; when they get 100 points they can leave the room and return to life. Oh yeah, and then Titz shows up. This is Titz. She has a real name but I'm not going to double-click the page where she introduces herself. She killed herself because she thinks she's worthless and that's probably the second most intelligent decision she's ever made. I've put up with crappy female characters before, but it seems that Titz is there solely to 1) Talk about how much she loves Masaru and 2) have breasts. If the artist could get away with just a pair of boobies tattoed with "I love Masaru" he could save a lot of wasted time drawing the rest of her. Of couse, since she's hot, Kei falls in love with h-.... Kei really, really wants to fuck her and that's the same thing as love, right? Of course it is! But Titz ain't having any of what Kei has to dish out; that's probably the smartest decision she's made. So that's the first ONE HUNDRED CHAPTERS of GANTZ . They go out. They kill shit. Other members of their "team" die, but they were extras anyway. Kei moons over Titz, Titz moons over Masaru, Masaru is all noble and shit. If you don't like violence, gore, and so many tit shots that I've lost count; GANTZ is not the story for you. If you like plot, character development, strong female characters, and romantic dialogue better than "I like... pets. PLEASE HAVE SEX WITH ME!" stay the fuck away until chapter 120 or so. GANTZ: So Bad It's Good. Sorta. urlLink http://www.omanga.net/?cid=gantz Next Week: Yakitate!! Japan (What, you thought *I* named her that?)

urlLink teehee! In his published testimony to the committee, Cassell pointed out that lower courts around the country are hastily cooking up ways to comply with Blakely. Some, believing themselves unable to depart upward from the guidelines, have imposed lower sentences than they'd like (hence the West Virginia drug manufacturer who saw his sentence decrease from 240 months to 12). Some have ruled that under Blakely, judges cannot depart upward from a fixed sentence but can nevertheless go downward. Others have simply put their jurors to back work—determining the truth of each of the aggravating factors once considered solely by the judge. Prosecutors are scrambling to figure out ways to keep defense attorneys from scoring reduced sentences based on Blakely arguments. ( Watch tomorrow's Martha Stewart sentencing for some serious Blakely-palooza. ) As Cassell puts it, calling this situation a crisis minimizes the efforts of serious judges on the ground who are hard at work making sense of the decision.

It's axiomatic that rich people are likely to be more optimistic and confident than those with less money, so the raw differentials aren't that surprising. But in the past few years, the readings for all income groups have generally moved in the same direction. If the economy were undergoing a broad-based expansion, if a rising tide were lifting all boats equally, you might expect that trend to continue. But the views of the rich and poor are moving in opposite directions. The split results-the growing pessimism of the poor and the growing optimism of the rich-suggest the economy's improvement isn't helping everyone.

So the new XP Service Pack is gonna roll out soon. From urlLink Cnet Downside: For one thing, this service pack is late. Had it arrived just three weeks earlier, the world may have been spared damage from Sasser and other viruses. And the download isn't small. For someone who hasn't downloaded a Windows update for eons, the file can top off at 270MB, but Microsoft estimates that most downloads (for folks who have been good about running Automatic Updates) will come closer to 100MB. As with any service pack, we wouldn't be surprised to see a couple of compatibility issues between SP2 and some apps already installed on your PC. Microsoft assures us it's doing everything it can to combat app compatibility issues, but we suggest exercising caution and waiting a few weeks tdsfo see if there are any major problems with SP2 before installing it.
